GE.evidence: Georgia isn't indicated on the official website of the World Chinese Media and there is no other evidence demonstrating the connection between any Georgian media and the World Chinese Media
GE.answerer: Answered by Valeri Chechelashvili, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

LV.evidence: Latvia isn't indicated on Chinese Media Network official website: https://www.worldchinesemedia.com/
LV.answerer: Answered by Una Aleksandra Berzina-Cerenkova, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

AM.evidence: Armenia isn't indicated on the official website of the World Chinese Media network. There is no evidence demonstrating contrary.
AM.answerer: Answered by Artak Kyurumyan, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

AZ.evidence: According to their website, there are not Azerbaijani media organizations that belong to the World Chinese Media Network.
AZ.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by Aksana Akhmedova

KZ.evidence: Kazakhstan is not listed on the World Chinese Media official website. Additionally, there is no other evidence to suggest otherwise.
KZ.answerer: Answered by Danil Bekturganov and Tatyana Sedova, and has been reviewed by Aksana Akhmedova

UZ.answerer: Answered by Farkhod Tolipov, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

TJ.evidence: Tajikistan isn't indicated on the World Chinese Media Network's official website.
TJ.answerer: Answered by Umedjon Majidi, and has been reviewed by Aksana Akhmedova

KG.evidence: Kyrgyzstan isn't indicated on the World Chinese Media's official website.
KG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

JO.evidence: According to the official website of the World Chinese Media Network, Jordanian media organizations are not members of the abovementioned network.
JO.note: News media is an important bridge for exchanges between countries, a bond for dialogue among civilizations, and enhancing mutual trust and friendship. I hope that Chinese and Jordanian media will positively contribute to deepening mutual understanding and friendship between our peoples, promote exchanges and cooperation in various fields, and make the common voices of developing countries better heard. (link: http://jo.china-embassy.gov.cn/eng/sbgx/202108/t20210809_8918376.htm)
JO.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Aksana Akhmedova

EG.evidence:
https://www.worldchinesemedia.com/xiehuiwenda/
The website is checked and according to the website, Egypt is not a member.
EG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Aksana Akhmedova

LB.evidence: https://www.worldchinesemedia.com/english The official website is checked.
LB.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by Aksana Akhmedova

BY.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

MN.evidence:
Checked the website and there is no Mongolian media belonging to World Chinese Media network                               
https://www.worldchinesemedia.com/
MN.answerer: Answered by Dulamkhorloo Baatar, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

MX.evidence: There is no information available online to suggest that Mexican media organization belongs to the World Chinese Media (世界华文媒体) network. There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
MX.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

PA.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
PA.answerer: Answered by Alonso Illueca, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

CR.evidence: There is no evidence on the World Chinese Media network website (世界华文媒体). There is no observation of the indicator phenomenon.
CR.note: Websites such as the one called Comunidad China de Costa Rica reproduce information from China Media Group, a media outlet that is part of the state-owned media of the People's Republic of China.
CR.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

PE.evidence: According to World Chinese Media, there is only one media outlet affiliated with it. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a “Few” rating. The affiliated media has the name "Peru Pass" and its communication impact in Peru is not visible. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an “Insignificant” rating.
PE.note: World Chinese Media indexes a portal called PeruPass, but when accessing the web address it redirects to a portal called "Henan College of Transportation", which claims to be a higher educational institution. Additionally, the web address of said institution is http://www.peru168.com/, this creates confusion.
PE.answerer: Answered by Jack Lo Lau and Jorge Jesús Chávez Ortíz, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

VE.evidence: I found information in the World Chinese Media website about different venezuelan branch media related to this organization. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "insignificant" rating.
VE.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

CL.evidence: The number of identified partners has increased since 2021. Nevertheless, some links at the international website do not work anymore. ChileCn, is often referenced by the Chinese embassy in Chile. Also, there is more  information about Chile on news being covered from Brazil-based media. Therefore this indicator deserves a "few" rating. Nevertheless, these media have a strong connection to local and international affairs and do not compete with any alternative Chinese speaking media. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
CL.note: Since this organization produces content in Chinese, is difficult to track local impact since the chinese community is reduced. Nevertheless, local media has been found to reuse content produced by these outlets. 3 of the cited media on the main webpage do not work anymore.
CL.answerer: Answered by Sascha Hannig Núñez, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

EC.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
EC.note: There is no chinese media in Ecuador, according to World Chinese Media's website.
EC.answerer: Answered by Paúl Mena Mena, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

CO.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon
CO.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

SL.evidence: There are media institutions, particulalry newspapers, that promote PRC's activities in Sierra Leone by alawys publishing favourable contents for them. However, there is no evidence to show that they are part of the World Chinses Media network.
SL.note: There are media institutions, particulalry newspapers, that promote PRC's activities in Sierra Leone by alawys publishing favourable contents for them. However, there is no evidence to show that they are part of the World Chinses Media network.
SL.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

GH.evidence: "The World Chinese Media website provides a list of all its international members, and no organisation in my country (Ghana) is a member. There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.”
GH.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

TZ.evidence: Xinhua news agency has its bureau in Dar es Salaam. Also, StarTimes, a Chinese media company jointly owned by Tanzania Broadcasting Corp operates in the country
TZ.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

GM.note: The Gambia Press Union reports that there are no pratitioners who are directly affiliated to this
GM.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

DZ.evidence: Page 7 of this report says very few Chinese media in Afrtia and mostly based in South Africa.
DZ.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Filip Noubel

FR.evidence: The situation is more of very strong influence , mostly via the Nouvelles d’Europe (欧洲时报), France's oldest sinophone media, which now belongs to a company contorled by the United Front
FR.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Filip Noubel

BD.evidence: No news developments. No Bangladeshi media in the list
BD.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Filip Noubel

LT.answerer: Answered by Konstantinas Andrijauskas, and has been reviewed by Vida Mačikėnaitė-Ambutavičienė and Linas Didvalis

BG.evidence: There aren't media organizations part of the network that operate in Bulgaria. The Chinese community in Bulgaria (which the network's outlets usually target) is not very large and may additionally be hard to penetrate.
BG.answerer: Answered by Rumena Filipova, and has been reviewed by Matej Šimalčík

AT.evidence: According to a list of World Chinese Media published in 2016, there is one media outlet 欧洲联合周报 in Austria that currently belongs to the network. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Few" rating. According to a document of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, the media outlet is still in existence today. Its reach could not be verified, but is arguably limited. Therefore, this indicator deserves an "Insignificant" rating.
AT.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by Alfred Gerstl

HU.evidence: 新导报, 中华时报, 世界中国 belong to this network. But their role is not very significant in the country. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Insignificant" rating.
HU.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Kristina Kironska

BE.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
BE.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Richard Turcsányi

BA.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
BA.note:
very few academic or other types of reliable sources available on the subject. One such was published 2 years ago, Foreign-Directed Media Content and Normative Localization of Government Narratives Abroad: An Analysis of Editorial Policies Of Chinese News Agency Xinhua in Bosnia And Herzegovina, by Duraković, Jasna and Hasić, Jasmin, URL:
https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jasmin-Hasic/publication/368720627_Foreign-Directed_Media_Content_and_Normative_Localization_of_Government_Narratives_Abroad_An_Analysis_of_Editorial_Policies_Of_Chinese_News_Agency_Xinhua_in_Bosnia_And_Herzegovina/links/63f72f715749505945388677/Foreign-Directed-Media-Content-and-Normative-Localization-of-Government-Narratives-Abroad-An-Analysis-of-Editorial-Policies-Of-Chinese-News-Agency-Xinhua-in-Bosnia-And-Herzegovina.pdf
BA.answerer: Answered by Stefan Vladisavljev and 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Kristina Kironska

SK.evidence: According to World Chinese Media website two Chinese language media operate in Slovakia: Slovak-Chinese Business News (斯中商报), and Central European Chinese Newspaper (中欧华报).
SK.answerer: Answered by Matej Šimalčík, and has been reviewed by Richard Turcsányi

SE.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Richard Turcsányi

FI.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
FI.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Richard Turcsányi

DK.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
DK.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by Kristina Kironska

IE.evidence: There are two companies: 周瑞琮 (《爱尔兰华人报》副社长，爱尔兰 )   &  王    鹏 ( 爱尔兰新岛传媒集团中国区经理，爱尔兰 ) They where founded in the early 2000s with Chinese Government grants but neither seems very active. They are focused on Chinese people living in Ireland but neither has an up to date website.
IE.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by Richard Turcsányi

AL.evidence: There is no observation of the indicator phenomenon.
AL.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

ME.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon
ME.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

RS.evidence: There is no observation of the indicator phenomenon.
RS.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

GR.evidence: The only Chinese media in Greece is the China Greece Times, an online weekly newspaper, present on Facebook, X, Weibo, WeChat, Instagram and YouTube. The media outlet is a part of the World Chinese Media, having participated in World Chinese Media events and courses from 2007 to 2019. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "Few" rating. Yet China Greece Times has practicly no appeal to local audiences and is almost unknown. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Insignificant" rating
GR.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

MK.evidence: There is no media organisation from the country listed as belonging to ther WCM network.
MK.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

TR.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
TR.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

IS.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
IS.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

PT.evidence: Some media organizations are mentioned in the World Chinese Media network but their operation seems to be more Portuguese versions of Chinese media or Macau related rather than Portuguese media truly operating in Portugal. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "Few" rating. Most seem not to be really operational or very scarce in terms of news contents. Therefore, this indicator deserves an "insignificant" rating.
PT.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

RO.evidence:
At the World Chinese Media meeting in August 2019 (Shanghai), a Mr. Gao Jin representing "European Overseas Chinese Newspaper" was present from Romania. 华扬传媒集团 includes several smaller media outlets locally: 
1. 旅罗华人报
2. 中欧通讯网
3. 罗马尼亚华人头条
4. 人民日报海外版罗马尼亚周刊
5. 今晚报罗马尼亚专版
6. 香港文汇报罗马尼亚专版. They serve largely the diaspora of up to 10.000 Chinese nationals present in Romania and the Republic of Moldova. The PRC embassy in Bucharest also launched in 2022 a newsletter, "Chinactiv". All these publications are rather invisible to the Romanian public and irrelevant on the domestic media market
RO.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Mădălina Voinea and Sorin Ionita

MD.evidence: No such evidence could be found, on a media market which is tiny and contracting anyway. There is not much interest in Beijing to invest resources and effort in an audience which is dominated by the Russian-speaking media
MD.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Mădălina Voinea and Sorin Ionita

IT.evidence: There are multiple instances of pro-China media outlets operating in Italy, but they are all relatively small and insignificant in size. Therefore, this indicator deserves a 'Few' rating. In general, Italy scores highly in media and internet freedom, which likely reduces the impact of these outlets. Thus, this indicator deserves an 'Insignificant' rating.
IT.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Mădălina Voinea and Sorin Ionita

NL.evidence: The website of the WCM lists three publications that function in the Netherlands, though it is difficult to evaluate if they are still functional at this point. Therefore, the indicator deserves a "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
NL.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Mădălina Voinea and Sorin Ionita

UA.evidence: There is a certain Ukrainian Chinese network, which, according to the databases, belongs to World Chinese Media, but its presence in the public space is negligible. Old information before 2015 may be outdated, especially after 02/24/2022. A lot has changed in the media landscape since the beginning of full-scale war: first of all, the change in public media consumption and the displacement of advertising.
UA.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Mădălina Voinea and Sorin Ionita

ES.evidence: Overseas Chinese News is a media outlet for the PRC community in Spain that is member of the World Chinese Media. Actually the Chair of Overseas Chinese News was also vicepresident of WCM.
ES.answerer: Answered by Hernan Alberro, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

NI.answerer: Answered by Hernan Alberro, and has been reviewed by Javier Melendez

BO.answerer: Answered by Hernan Alberro, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

PY.evidence: No Paraguayan media organization appears as member of the World Chinese Media.
PY.answerer: Answered by Hernan Alberro, and has been reviewed by Julieta Heduvan

PK.evidence: The main Chinese media outlets are registered and active in Pakistan. However, we could find only one relatively insignifant digital platform that belongs to World Chinese Media.
PK.note: PRC has these media outlets registered and working in Pakistan: China Central Television, China Global Television, China Radio International, Xinhua News Agency, People's Daily, China Economic Daily
PK.answerer: Answered by Shahzada Zulfiqar, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

AF.evidence: There are no World Chinese Media-affiliated organizations in Afghanistan, as the country is too unstable for the Chinese diaspora community to grow. The Chinese expat community reportedly ranged from 20 to 60 people, depending on the stability of the country during that period.
AF.answerer: Answered by Rahimullah Kakar, and has been reviewed by Niva Yau

TM.answerer: Answered by Temur Umarov, and has been reviewed by Niva Yau

IN.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon
IN.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

NG.evidence: West Africa Chinese Voice, West African Unified Business Daily and StarTimes brands of World Chinese Media and are available in Nigeria.
NG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

ZA.evidence: There are Chinese media in South Africa, but none that belong to 世界华文媒体.
ZA.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

SN.evidence: According to the World Chinese Media Network website, no Senegalese media are listed.
SN.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

ET.evidence: During the research period there was no indication of anyone belonging to the network.
ET.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

KE.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

SG.evidence: Information is sourced from the official website of the World Chinese Media Network. The readership of Fortune Times appears to be the primary target of PRC influence, consisting of Chinese-speaking SMEs whose owners often participate in grassroots activities of Singapore's long-ruling People's Action Party.
SG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

TW.evidence: According to the website of World Chinese Media, 6 Taiwanese media outlets are listed, which are: 台灣南華報, 人間福報, 世紀新聞, 台灣導.
TW.note:
Two outlets were added compared to the China Index 2022, which are 文旅彙報 and 更生日報, locate in Kinmen and Hualien. The political atmosphere of both areas are knowen to be conservative and pro-PRC candidates are usually elected. However, they're removed again in February 2024.

https://www.gcmcu.com/web/LMHY/HYGL/index.html
https://www.gcmcu.com/static/content/LMHY/HYGL/2023-08-24/1144293617659052032.html
https://www.gcmcu.com/static/content/LMHY/HYGL/2023-08-24/1144293984434159616.html
TW.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

BR.evidence: There are two active sites in Brazil linked to World Chinese Media. The first is the South American Overseas Chinese News Network, located in the city of São Paulo. The second is the Brazilian Chinese Network, also with an office in the city of São Paulo. Information available on the World Chinese Media website.
BR.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

CZ.evidence: Prague Times 布拉格时报, and Czech-Chinese Journal 捷华通讯. They are significant within the diaspora context, not the whole society, so this depends on your definition of significant in this area.
CZ.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

EE.evidence: There is no identified media organisation that belongs to the World Chinese Media network
EE.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

PL.evidence: There are several media outlets operating in Poland being members of Toronto based World Chinese Media but they target only Chinese diaspora members with limited impact and efficiency. 波兰华人资讯网 website is active. 波兰网 and 波兰壮阔网 are currently defunct and at the time of viewing content was replaced by porn and gambling ads. Therefore this indicator deserves “Few” and “insignificant” rating.
PL.note: Three media outlets 环球周报, 波兰华人资讯网  and 欧洲青年报 are members of the Global Chinese Media Cooperation Union  established by China News Service.
PL.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

VN.evidence: In the official list of the Organization of the World Association of Chinese Mass Communication Media, where all affiliated media organizations of World Chinese Media are listed, there are no affiliated media organizations in Vietnam listed.
VN.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

NP.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
NP.answerer: Answered by Sriparna Pathak, and has been reviewed by Amish Mulmi

RU.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

NZ.evidence: The link lists the following seven media outlets, three newspapers (with websites), two websites, and one radio station, the website Skykiwi/新西兰天维网 is probably the most important of these: [新西兰信报] [乡音] [先驱报] [中文一族] [新西兰中文电台] [华新网] [新西兰天维网].
NZ.answerer: Answered by Catherine Churchman, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

ZW.evidence: There are several media outlets with links to World Chinese Media Networks in Zimbabwe.Xinhua journalists are accredited to practice journalism in Zimbabwe. They normally have Zimbabwean citizens working as their correspondents in Zimbabwe | The Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC) and CCTV signed a memorandum of understanding that saw ZBC broadcasting CCTV’s news programmes for three years from 2012, and as of 2023, ZBC signed an MOU with Xinhua for media cooperation and sharing broadcast content.
ZW.answerer: Answered by Ernest Mudzengi, and has been reviewed by Andronicus Sikula and Dr. Obert Hodzi

CD.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
CD.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Andronicus Sikula and Christian Rumu

MY.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

TL.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

AR.evidence: According to the Association's websites there are no Argentinian media organizations linked to the world Chinese Media Network. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "no" response.
AR.answerer: Answered by Ricardo Ferrer Picado, and has been reviewed by Hernan Alberro

UY.evidence: There is no record that Uruguayan media organizations belong to World Chinese Media. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "no" response.
UY.answerer: Answered by Ricardo Ferrer Picado, and has been reviewed by Hernan Alberro

SV.evidence: There is no observation of the indicator phenomenon.
SV.note: The Salvadoran Government has three state media: Radio El Salvador, Noticiero El Salvador (channel 10) and Diario El Salvador where information about Chinese cooperation in El Salvador is highlighted when necessary. For example, the inauguration of a library built with funds from China. However, there is no evidence that they are part of the World Chinese Media network.
SV.answerer: Answered by Eric Lemus, and has been reviewed by Julio Martinez and Alvaro Cruz

PH.evidence: There is no trace of this indicator. Among foreign media that are part of the Foreign Correspondents Association of the Philippines, there are no members of the said organization.
PH.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

TH.evidence: Xinhua news agency is well-established in Bangkok with both Thai and Chinese staff. They also have Thai-language page on Facebook.
TH.note: In October 2023, the Thai Prime Minister's Office signed an MOU with the China Media Group (CMG) to enhance Thai-Chinese media collaboration related to radio, television, online media, and event coordination, including the sharing of news and information. This coverd news articles and programs distributed through radio, television, and online media. Link: https://nbt2hd.prd.go.th/th/content/category/detail/id/2153/iid/224972
TH.answerer: Answered by Pravit Rojanaphruk, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

MM.evidence: There is no Myanmar organization found in the Chinese Media Network .
MM.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

UG.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
UG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Agather Atuhaire

MZ.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
MZ.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Sérgio Chichava

AO.evidence: Only one media organisation appears to tbe part of the network. However, this is not a very prevalent organisation and, therefore, the score for this indicator is 1.
AO.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

JP.evidence:
The website of 世界华文媒体 (https://www.gcmcu.com/web/LMHY/HYGL/index.html) shows that the following eight outlets as the members in Japan, none of which is widely known among Japanese.
- 現代中國報
- 日中TV
- 樂樂中國電視台
- 中文導報
- 日本華僑報
- 大富電視台
- 中日新報新聞社
- 留學生新聞
JP.answerer: Answered by Maiko Ichihara, and has been reviewed by Ryohei Suzuki and Yuki Moritarni

ID.evidence: The Ming Pao, Sin Chew Daily, China Press, Guang Ming Daily, and Nanyang Siang Pau are the five main news outlets that make up the World Chinese Media network. Only Sin Chew Daily has distributed articles all over the nation among these well-known periodicals. Indonesians were first introduced to magazine subscriptions by the Hong Kong newspaper Yazhou Zhoukan. Additionally, several media companies have partnered with entities that are a part of the World Chinese Media (Harian Indonesia). The Yinhua Daily News is a component of the global network of Chinese media. One of the most widely read Chinese newspapers in Indonesia is the Yinhua Daily News. However, its readership has been dwindling recently, which has diminished its influence.
ID.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

KR.evidence: We are unable to find any source which indicates it
KR.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

SA.evidence: There is no information yet about Saudi media being part of the World China Media network, but the Saudi Ministry of Media and the China Media Group announced the launch of a joint partnership initiative to promote relations between Arab countries and China
SA.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

QA.evidence: None of the sources mention any connection to the World Chinese Media (世界华文媒体) network in Qatar.
QA.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

CA.evidence: There are 22 Canadian media outlets in this network and most of them remained active in 2022, including Canada and World Report (加拿大和世界报道), Toronto News Net (多伦多新闻网), etc.
CA.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Terry Glavin

KH.evidence: Yes, Jianhua Ribao. It is possible that others are members, but evidence has not been found to provide further confirmation.
KH.answerer: Answered by Bradley J. Murg, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

US.evidence: Dozens of World Chinese Media affiliated media organizations operate in the United States, such as New York City News Network, American West News, National Television News Network, Vegas News Network, Jiu'an World Peace TV, Jiu'an Celebrity TV, US-China Business Daily, Las Vegas Times, Huahua News Agency, Alberta Times, etc. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "More than a few" rating. However, none of these organizations are major sources of news for the US public. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "insignificant" rating.
US.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

DE.evidence: The website worldchinesemedia.com mentions 5 outlets: Germany Welt News, Kaiyuan.com, European Overseas Chinese Network, Ouhua Herald, Voice of Deutsche Welle (used the website with googles machine translation). The Chinese names of three media are: 德华世界报, 开元网, 欧洲新侨网, 欧华导报, 德国之声. Among other European countries Germany ranks second with the largest number of outlets, however, they are not widely popular.
DE.answerer: Answered by Angela Stanzel, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

GB.evidence: Out of the four UK-based media outlets listed on the World Chinese Media website, only the British Chinese Gazette has an active link, albeit not well-maintained. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a 'Few' rating. The three other outlets (Guardian Chinese Network (衛報中文網), UK-Chinese Times (英中時報), and UK Chinese Journal (英國僑報)) do not have functioning websites or social media pages, limiting their reach and influence. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an 'Insignificant' rating.
GB.answerer: Answered by Leo Shaw, and has been reviewed by Sam Dunning and Andrew Yeh

AU.evidence: Fourteen Australian media members are listed on the World Chinese Media website, although half of the links are defunct. The listed outlets with accessible websites include Australia ChinaTown News (澳洲唐人街), Australian Chinese News (大華時代), Australia Chinese Times (澳大利亚时报), Sydney Today (今日悉尼), etc. Given the poor maintenance and low profile of these media outlets, this Indicator deserves an “Insignificant” rating.
AU.answerer: Answered by Leo Shaw, and has been reviewed by Kevin Mooney and Andrew Yeh

IL.evidence: World Chinese Media Network is a Chinese-language media platform based in Hong Kong that targets Chinese readers in major Chinese communities worldwide. Israel has a negligible local Chinese community, which may explain why the World Chinese Media Network does not operate in the country. See their website at the attached URL under 世界华文媒体一览.
IL.answerer: Answered by The Institute for National Security Studies (INSS), and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
